column4: Bo7: they are not the same. Both are optional depending on how you want your ssh to work
I want to put my public key in it to get access

known_hosts justs keeps track of hosts you've already contacted, as a precaution against someone impersonating a server. You can delete it at any time and ssh will rebuild it adding entries each time you visit a new site

known_hosts justs keeps track of hosts you've already contacted, as a precaution against someone impersonating a server. You can delete it at any time and ssh will rebuild it adding entries each time you visit a new site
can i just create the autorized_keys then?
for public key access, you need to take the CLIENTs public key and put it into the SERVERs authorized_keys file.
I'm trying to get access from a windows machine
using putty?
losher,yeah
have you checked the putty FAQ?
I'll check it again ;)   so I don't need to generate any keys on the server at all?
just on the client right?
right. Only the client needs a public/private key pair, and the public key needs to be copied to the servers authorized_keys file
I see. what does the id_rsa.keystore file do on the server?
wow, dunno. Anyone?
i've got an id_rsa + id_rsa.pub and now this id.rsa.keystore
if it's on the client, I don't think it will matter. The important part is that the server has to have the clients id_rsa.pub in the servers authorized_keys file
allright thx for the help!
Be careful how you copy it. If you cut&paste it, you can introduce linefeeds which aren't there in the original
okay thx
come back if you get stuck...
will do, thx :)
